November 11, 2012: Fiction
THE RACKETEER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Malcolm Bannister, an
imprisoned ex-lawyer, knows who murdered a federal judge. And he concocts a
scheme to exchange this information for his freedom.
THE PANTHER, by Nelson DeMille. (Grand Central, $27.99.) The anti-terrorist task
force agent John Corey and his wife, an F.B.I. agent, pursue a high-ranking Qaeda
operative.
THE CASUAL VACANCY, by J. K. Rowling. (Little, Brown, $35.) The sudden death
of a parish councilman reveals bitter social divisions in an idyllic English town; a
novel for adults by the creator of Harry Potter.
BACK TO BLOOD, by Tom Wolfe. (Little, Brown, $30.) A Cuban-American cop is a
hero turned pariah in Miami, where ethnic and class tensions threaten to explode.
THE BRIDGE, by Karen Kingsbury. (Howard Books, $19.99.) The destruction of a
beloved bookstore offers the shop’s supporters second chances on love and
leases.
THE BONE BED, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $28.95.) A paleontologist’s
disappearance in Canada turns out to be connected to crimes much closer to home
for the chief medical examiner Kay Scarpetta; the 20th Scarpetta book.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
NYPD RED, by James Patterson and Marshall Karp. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
Detective Zach Jordan and his beautiful partner (and ex-girlfriend) must stop a
deranged killer who has targeted a glittering New York film festival.
ANGELS AT THE TABLE, by Debbie Macomber. (Ballantine, $18.) Angels cook up
a plan to reunite a young couple.
WINTER OF THE WORLD, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $36.) Members of five
interrelated families from five countries grapple with the historical events of the
THE TWELVE, by Justin Cronin. (Ballantine, $28.) A sequel to “The Passage”
continues its story of life after an apocalypse.
THE TIME KEEPER, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $24.99.) A fable about the
inventor of the world’s first clock from the author of “Tuesdays With Morrie.”
THE YELLOW BIRDS, by Kevin Powers. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) A young soldier
goes to battle in Iraq and has trouble adjusting once back home.
MAD RIVER, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $27.95.) Virgil Flowers joins the hunt for
November 11, 2012
Non-Fiction
KILLING KENNEDY, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of “The
O’Reilly Factor” recounts the events surrounding the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
NO EASY DAY, by Mark Owen with Kevin Maurer. (Dutton, $26.95.) An account by a
former member of the Navy SEALs, written pseudonymously, of the mission that killed
bin Laden.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of "The
O'Reilly Factor" recounts the events surrounding the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
ROD, by Rod Stewart. (Crown Archetype, $27.) The pop singer reminisces on his long
career.
THE SIGNAL AND THE NOISE, by Nate Silver. (Penguin Press, $27.95.) An
examination of predictions, the ones that come true and the ones that don’t.
PROOF OF HEAVEN, by Eben Alexander. (Simon & Schuster, $21.99.) A
neurosurgeon recounts his near death experience during a coma from bacterial
meningitis.
MAKEUP TO BREAKUP, by Peter Criss with Larry Sloman. (Scribner, $26.) The Kiss
drummer reflects on his life in rock.
HOW CHILDREN SUCCEED, by Paul Tough. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $27.) The
author argues that the qualities that matter most have to do with character, not
intelligence.
AMERICA AGAIN, by Stephen Colbert, Richard Dahm, Paul Dinello, Barry Julien, Tom
Purcell et al.. (Grand Central, $28.99.) The mock pundit of Comedy Central’s “Colbert
Report” tells how to bring America back from the brink.
PLUTOCRATS, by Chrystia Freeland. (Penguin Press, $27.95.) The lives of the global
elites in the wealthiest 0.1 percent and the consequences of increasing income
stratification.
WHO I AM, by Pete Townshend. (Harper/HarperCollins, $32.5.) The rocker's memoir.
WAGING HEAVY PEACE, by Neil Young. (Blue Rider, $30.) The rocker’s memoir
ranges over his personal life and his music, including his days with Buffalo Springfield
and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young.
WHY I LEFT GOLDMAN SACHS, by Greg Smith. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A former
equity derivatives executive offers his analysis of investment bank culture.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's story of
survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
